conclusion: Analyze forces acting on hemispheres A and B using equilibrium and friction conditions.
Hemispheres A and B are between vertical walls, with a line between centers at a 30Â° angle to horizontal.
Identify forces acting on hemisphere A: weight, normal force from wall, frictional force from wall, normal force from hemisphere B, components of normal force from B and weight of B.
Vertical forces on hemisphere A must balance: \( N_{AB} \sin(30^\circ) = mg \), leading to \( N_{AB} = 2mg \).
Horizontal forces on hemisphere A must balance: \( N_{AB} \cos(30^\circ) = f_A \), leading to \( f_A = \sqrt{3}mg \).
Maximum static friction force is \( f_{\text{max}} = \mu_s N_A \), and \( f_A = \mu_s N_A \) since hemispheres are just not sliding.
Determine normal force \( N_A \) as sum of vertical components: \( N_A = \left( \sqrt{3} + \frac{1}{2} \right)mg \).
Final answer for dynamic friction coefficient is \( \boxed{\frac{2\sqrt{3}}{2\sqrt{3} + 1}} \).
